questions.text: Which of the following is not an aetiological factor for developing Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : D) Autosomal recessive inheritance

Explanation:

Autosomal recessive inheritance is not an aetiological factor for developing PCOS.

Aetiology of PCOS:

  • Genetic predisposition- CYP21 gene mutation.
  • Insulin resistance
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Chronic stress
  • Exposure to environmental toxins.
  • Sedentary lifestyle and diet
  • Obesity
  • Type 1&2 DM
  • Anti-epileptic drugs like Valproic acid
  • Mexican/Australian or South Asian ethnicity

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and excessive hair growth. An ultrasound reveals multiple ovarian cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Explanation:

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

Components of PCOS:

  • Increased androgens
  • Ovulatory dysfunction
  • Polycystic ovaries

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance

Endometriosis (Option B) involves the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus and presents with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea and infertility. While it can cause irregular menstrual cycles, it does not typically cause acne, hirsutism, or multiple ovarian cysts.

Hypothyroidism (Option C) can cause menstrual irregularities, weight gain, and fatigue. However, it does not commonly present with acne, hirsutism, or multiple ovarian cysts.

Hyperprolactinemia (Option D) is characterised by elevated levels of prolactin in the blood and can cause galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances, and infertility. It is not typically associated with acne, hirsutism, or the presence of multiple ovarian cysts.

questions.text: All of the following criteria are used for diagnosing PCOS except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Elevated estrogen levels

Explanation:

Elevated estrogen levels can occur in some cases of PCOS due to disturbances in hormone regulation, it is not a primary diagnostic criterion for PCOS.

Rotterdam Criteria:

Any 2 of the following 3 should be present to make a provisional diagnosis for PCOS

(Option A) Increased androgen levels: Hyperandrogenism/Hirsutism: PCOS is associated with elevated androgen levels, which can manifest as clinical signs (like hirsutism and acne) or biochemical findings (elevated testosterone).

(Option B) Ovulatory dysfunction: Oligomenorrhea/Amenorrhea- Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea) or absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea) are common features of PCOS due to ovulatory dysfunction.

(Option D) On USG: 1 or both ovaries >12 follicles with 2-9mm in size (<1cm)- One of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS is the presence of polycystic ovarian morphology, which is confirmed by ultrasound showing multiple cysts on the ovaries.

USG: Necklace pattern arranged towards the periphery.

questions.text: Select the incorrect laboratory findings associated with PCOS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fasting glucose : Fasting insulin ratio >4.5

Explanation:

A fasting glucose-to-insulin ratio of less than 4.5 is characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome.

 

Hormonal profiles of PCOS:

  • Increased LH/FSH ratio: Dysregulation of gonadotropin secretion.
  • Decreased progesterone levels: Due to irregular menstrual cycles and ovulatory dysfunction.
  • Abnormal insulin sensitivity: Insulin resistance is commonly associated with PCOS, leading to compensatory hyperinsulinemia.
  • Increased Estradiol (E2) levels
  • Increased LH levels
  • Increased Androgens
  • Increased dehydroepiandrosterone
  • 17 alpha hydroxyprogesterone > 300ng/dL
  • Testosterone > 2ng/mL
  • Increased Prolactin
  • Decreased Sex Hormone Binding Globulin(SHBG)
  • Decreased E2/E1 ratio
  • Fasting glucose/ Fastinginsulin ratio < 4.5

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who is a known case of PCOS for the past 10 years is at increased risk of all the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Ca Cervix

Explanation

Long term Sequelae:-

  • Development of diabetes, hypertension, Cardiovascular disease, hyperlipidemia, endometrial cancer. (Option A, B, C)
  • Thus, they have to followed up properly for their ailments.

Lifestyle changes are recommended: Obesity in adolescents needs to be corrected.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of irregular menstrual cycle and weight gain. You diagnose her with PCOS. What is the first line of management for regularising her menstrual cycles?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) OCPs

Explanation :

Management of PCOS

  • OCPs
  • OCPs containing cyproterone acetate or drospirenone (if acne and hirsutism present)
  • OCPs and spironolactone

Oestrogen suppresses androgens and adrenal hormones.

It raises the secretion of SHBG in the liver thereby reducing the free testosterone.

It also suppresses LH.

It is given as low-dose combined pills having progestogen with lesser androgenic effect.

Fourth-generation combined pills are preferred.

It also prevents further acne and hirsutism development.

questions.text: A 35 year old female comes to OPD complaining of being unable to conceive for 3 years. She is a known case of PCOS. Which of the following drugs will you recommend?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Clomiphene Citrate

Explanation :

Drugs used to treat Infertility in PCOS

Letrozole (preferred over clomiphene citrate)

  • aromatase inhibitors
  • No antiestrogenic action on the endometrium and cervix thus yielding better pregnancy rate.
  • Induces Mono Follicular stimulation, thus avoiding multiple pregnancy
  • No hyperstimulation syndrome
  • Side effect - drowsiness

Clomiphene citrate (Option B)

  • Unlike letrozole, it has anti-estrogenic action on the endometrium and cervix, thereby decreasing the fertility rate.
  • It can cause hyperstimulation Syndrome in <1% of patients.
  • It induces ovulation in 80% of the cases and 40-45% conceive.
  • Co-administration of dexamethasone leads to better outcomes.
  • In resistant cases, Tamoxifen 80-160 mg daily for 5 days tried.

Metformin

  • It is used as an insulin sensitiser.
  • Reduces the insulin level, delays glucose absorption and production of glucose in the liver
  • It also improves the peripheral utilisation of the glucose. Reduces the free and total testosterone increases SHBG.
  • Contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease

Nowadays, instead of Metformin, some gynaecologists prefer using N-acetyl cysteine with micronutrients. This reduces the homocysteine level.

Ketoconazole 800mg daily reduces testosterone secretion.

If medical management fails, then surgical management can be undertaken.

questions.text: An 18 year old girl comes to the OPD with complaints of irregular cycles, weight gain and excessive hair growth on the face. You are suspecting PCOS. What will be the initial management for hirsutism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) OCPs with cyproterone acetate

 

Explanation :

Acne and Hirsutism treatment in PCOS

OCPs with Anti Androgens (fourth generation combined pills are preferred)

  • Oral combined pills with Cyproterone acetate (DOC)
  • Oral combined pills with spironolactone

 

Lifestyle changes

  • Weight loss eg. more than 5% of previous weight alone
  • Cigarette smoking stopped
